newsitem.title: ITALY: EU to rule Alitalia cash state aid - report.
newsitem.headline: EU to rule Alitalia cash state aid - report.

text.p: European Transport Commissioner Neil Kinnock has decided that a recapitalisation of troubled Italian flag carrier Alitalia must be classed as state aid and not a market investment, Corriere della Sera reported on Friday.
The newspaper said Kinnock's decision, which will be finalised in a couple of weeks, would also cut the amount to 2.75 trillion lire from three trillion lire.
Italy last year requested EU permission for a capital injection worth some 3.3 trillion lire to rescue the debt-ladden, state-controlled airline.
Alitalia's managing director Domenico Cempella said last month that the Commission had suggested a reduction to 2.8 trillion lire.

Italy argues that the capital injection does not amount to state subsidies, but that it is acting in accordance with its right as a shareholder in the company -- a view which the Commission has rejected in many other airline rescue plans.
Corriere said, however, that Alitalia's negotiations with Kinnock had succeeded in easing some of the strict conditions that are usually attached to the granting of state aid.
Alitalia would not be allowed to offer the lowest price on any route to avoid charges of state-sponsored dumping, it said.
Alitalia declined to comment on the report. "The decision is due in mid-July," a spokesman said. There was no immediate comment from Brussels.

The newspaper said Kinnock's decision should confirm a 14-plane cut in the fleet, the loss of 27,000 flights a year and a 10 percent reduction in activity on European routes as outlined by Cempella in March after the Commission sent the rescue plan back to Italy for changes.
Kinnock would also seek an increase in job losses to 2,100 from the 1,850 planned, it said.

Commercial director Federico Nucci said earlier this month that Alitalia's current performance was ahead of forecasts. "If we can continue in this actual trend we will not close 1997 at breakeven, but with a significant profit," he said.
Alitalia had a group net consolidated loss of 1.203 trillion lire in 1996, its ninth loss in a row.
